Mankind are becoming, every day, less dependent the locomotive powers that nature gave them.  The first time visited Philadelphia was in the depth of an unusally cold winter. some 1 fifteen or twenty years ago. I was welcomed, say, for Ihad a slight acquaintance with the Huberts; ! know them as a family once in affluent circumstan- ces, but by fortune that was inpenetrable as the mysteries of the tomb, a fate the secret history of which was locked up in their own bosoms. reduced to far deeper poverty than the peasant knows--tO life of want and wO. Penury does not always touch the heart: and it was easy to read, in glance at the group that gathered round the blaze Op that eve hing that the bas0ms of the Huberts had left deeper stabs that even simple penury could give. ~ The cabin was rudely formed of logs, from between which the clay plastering here and there having fallen out, left large crevices {; and one single room was all the dwelling con- tained. The furniture consisted of a couple of benches, an old stand, and few wooden dishes. In none of these were to seen the remains of that opulence of which learned the Huberts once were the possessors, but it was found in their family attire and the air still fingered about them. The old lady though negigently dressed had about her those touches of taste and refinement which cannot deceive. and Ellen Hubert though her cheeks were thin and pale, and her eyes heavy, perhaps with weeping. carried with her that grace of manner, and expression that reminded me of captive fairy in some deso- late region.

 She was young and fair; for, sorrow as if proud of its victims. only adds more deli cate. and'moving, and pathetic loveliness to beauty. As gazed, first on her then on the prattiing eherub. that stood beside her, a child of but three or four years, 1 read, thought with too great certainty, the cause of so much grief. A A poor wayfaring man of grief .g Hath often crossed me oR my way, Who sued so humbly for reiief, -e That could never answer N0y: had not power to ask his name, Whither he went or whence he came, Yet there was something in his eye That won my loye-I know not why. Once when my scanty meal was spread, @ He entered: not a word he spake: Just perishing for want of bread; gave him all; he blessed 1t, brake, And ate, but gave me part again; Mine was an angei's portion then, And while fed with eager haste, The crust was mama to my taste. spied him where fountain burst Clear from the rock: his strength was gone; The needless water mock d his thirst He heard it, saw it thurrying on; ran and raised the sufferer up, Thrice from the stream he drained my cup, Dipt, and returned 1t, running o'er; drank, and never thirsted more. Twas night, the floods were out, it blew A winter hurricane aloof; heard his voice abroad, and flew 4e To bid him welcome to my roof; 4gssa warmed, clothed, cheered my guest, laid him on my couch to rest, Then made the earth my bed, and seemed In Eden's garden while dreamed. Stript, wounded, beaten nigh to death, l found him by the highway side; reused his pulse, brought back his breath, Reyieed his spirit, and supplied Wine, oil, refreshment; he was healed; 2 --I had, myself, wound concealed, But from that hour forgot the smart, And peace bound up my broken heart. In prison saw hiau next-cOndemned To meet a traitors doom at morn: The tide of lying tone eues lstemmed, And honored him 'midst shame and scorn. My friendships utmost zeal to- try, He asked-ifI for him would die; The flesh was weak, my blood run chill, But the free Spirit cried, "I will" Then, in moment, to my view, The stranger darted from disguise; The tokens in his hands knew; My SAVIOUR stood before mine eyes, He spake, and my poor name he named-- "Of me thou hast not been ashamed; These deeds shall thy memorial be; Fear not, thon didst them unto me-" she0ieLd, Eng.
